questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with the following skin finding. Which of the following clinical signs will aid in Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auspitz Sign

 

Option B.

 

  • One defining characteristic of psoriasis is the presence of silvery white scaly plaques on the extensor aspect of the elbows and knees.
  • Its diagnosis is aided by the grattage test.
  • The act of scratching (grattage) psoriasis scales causes air keratin interfaces to form, giving the scales a more silvery appearance.
  • When all the scales are removed, the basement membrane becomes visible and appears as a moist, red surface (the Bulkley membrane), through which dilated capillaries at the tips of elongated dermal papillae are torn, creating numerous bleeding points.
  • The Auspitz sign is the name for the traditional pin-point bleeding.

 

 

Underlying Cause:

 

  • The Auspitz sign is caused by suprapapillary epidermal thinning and elongated, dilated, tortuous vessels in the dermal papillae.

 

However, the Auspitz sign is neither sensitive nor specific for psoriasis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Skin Biopsy:

 

  • It is a diagnostic procedure that can help to differentiate between various skin conditions by providing histopathological evidence.
  • However, it is not a clinical sign but rather a diagnostic tool and may not be necessary for classic presentations of psoriasis.

 

Option C. KOH Smear:

 

  • It is used to diagnose fungal infections by revealing fungal elements in the skin flakes when examined under a microscope.
  • This would not aid in diagnosing psoriasis, which is not a fungal infection.

 

Option D. Besnier’s Sign/Scratch Sign/Stroke of the Nail/Coup d’ongle Sign:

 

  • The fine branny scales of pityriasis versicolor may become visible after scratching the lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Auspitz sign is a clinical indicator of psoriasis, characterized by pinpoint bleeding when scales from a psoriatic plaque are scraped away.
  • This sign can be useful in the clinical diagnosis of psoriasis without the need for invasive testing.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 4 Page No 4.17-18

Journal: https://ijdvl.com/scaly-signs-in-dermatology/

https://ijdvl.com/telltale-signs-of-skin-trespassers-clues-to-superficial-mycosis/#:~:text=Besnier's%20sign%2Fscratch%20sign%2Fstroke,recent%20bath%20%5BFigure%201%5D.

choices.text: Nail Pitting seen is of Deep Irregular & Coarse Type
Joint involvement is seen in 5-30% of Patients
Deficient Th1 & Th17 Helper Cells

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding Psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Deficient TH1 & TH17 Cells

 

Option D. 

 

Psoriasis:

 

  • Option D is incorrect because psoriasis is associated with an overactive Th1 and Th17 immune response, not a deficiency.
  • Associated with a deficiency of Th2 cells.
  • These cells are involved in the pathogenesis of psoriasis by producing inflammatory cytokines that lead to the skin changes seen in this condition.
  • It is an inflammatory non-infectious disease.
  • Genetic predisposition is present in type 1 plaque psoriasis & guttate psoriasis with HLA C: 06: 02
  • About 5-30% of patients with cutaneous psoriasis have Psoriatic Arthritis (PsA).
  • At any given time, 40% of psoriasis cases have changes to their nails.
  • Nail Psoriasis is linked to more severe psoriasis, longer disease duration, psoriatic arthritis, and family history of the condition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nail Pitting

 

  • It is a common clinical feature of psoriasis.
  • The pitting is typically deep, irregular, and coarse, which helps differentiate it from the finer pitting seen in conditions like alopecia areata.

 

Option B. Genetic Predisposition

 

  • The HLA-C*06:02 allele is strongly associated with psoriasis, particularly with early-onset psoriasis.

 

Option C. Joint involvement

 

  • Psoriatic arthritis, which involves joint inflammation, occurs in 5-30% of patients with psoriasis.

 

Nail Changes in Psoriasis:

 

 

  • Salmon patches or subungual oil drop sign is extremely specific pathognomonic sign of nail psoriasis. It looks like an oil droplet and is a yellowish, reddish discoloration in the nail bed.
  • However, the most frequent symptom is nail pitting.
  • Individual pits are irregular in shape and uniform in depth. These nail pits, also referred to as Thimblepits, are brought on by the proximal nail matrix's involvement.
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis are additional symptoms of nail bed disease.
  • There might also be leukonychia.

 

 

  • Pitting affecting the fingernails.

 

 

  • Onycholysis along with pitting and salmon patches in fingernails

 

 

  • Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis

 

 

  • Nail plate thickening and crumbling resulting in complete nail dystrophy.
  • Features of Nail Psoriasis - Mnemonic
    • "Nail - POLISH"
  • P – Pitting (Most common feature)
  • O- Oil drop sign (Pathognomonic), Onycholysis
  • L - Leukonychia
  • I - Irregular pitting pattern
  • S - Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H - Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

 

Cytokines in psoriasis:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Psoriasis is associated with an increased Activity of Th1 and Th17 Helper Cells, contrary to a Deficiency, and recognize the clinical features and genetic predispositions linked to the Disease.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 Page No 35.4-35.6

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition Page No 333

questions.text: A patient presented to her primary care physician with an itchy scalp & dandruff. O/E the following finding was seen & True Koebner's phenomenon was present. The disease is LEAST likely to affect the?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Axilla

 

Chronic Plaque Psoriasis/ Psoriasis Vulgaris:

 

  • The above clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic plaque psoriasis/ Psoriasis vulgaris.
  • Psoriasis less commonly affects the axilla due to the nature of skin in this region being less prone to the chronic friction or trauma that typically induces the Koebner phenomenon.
  • Axilla is usually not involved in chronic plaque psoriasis.
  • Axilla is affected by inverse psoriasis.

 

Commonly affected sites are:

 

  • Scalp
  • Elbows
  • Knees
  • Lower back
  • Gluteal cleft

 

Inverse /Flexural psoriasis:

 

  • In Inverse Psoriasis, Flexural Plaques are Thin & Scaling is greatly Reduced or Absent.
  • In addition to other body folds, it affects the Inguinal Creases, Axillae, Sub Mammary Folds, Gluteal Cleft, and Umbilicus.
  • It is more prevalent in Older Adults and is linked to Obesity.
  • The image below shows inverse Psoriasis.

 

 

Koebner or Isomorphic Phenomenon:

 

  • It is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin.
  • The new lesions have Iso (same) &morphic (morphology) as existing lesions.
  • Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

 

 

  • The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

 

 

Some rare causes of true Koebner phenomenon are:

 

  • Darier's disease,
  • Hailey hailey disease,
  • EMF erythema multiforme,
  • Kaposi’s sarcoma &
  • lichen nitidus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Gluteal Cleft

 

  • Psoriasis can affect the gluteal cleft.

 

Option C. Lumbosacral Area

 

  • The lumbosacral area is a common site for plaque psoriasis, which can be exacerbated by factors like friction or pressure.

 

Option D. Elbows & Knees

 

  • These are classic sites for plaque psoriasis due to the frequent trauma and pressure experienced by these areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Axilla is the least likely location to be affected by psoriasis among the options provided, as psoriasis tends to occur in areas subjected to frequent pressure or trauma, which is less characteristic of the axillary region.

 

Ref: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 19th Edition Page No 347

Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 Page No 35.5

Online Resources:

https://www.uptodate.com/contents/psoriasis-epidemiology-clinical-manifestations-and-diagnosis

choices.text: Camel Foot Appearance of Rete Ridges

questions.text: Histopathology of Psoriasis is unlikely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wedge Shaped Hypergranulosis

 

Option D. 

 

Wedge Shaped Hypergranulosis: is a feature of Lichen planus (Not Psoriasis)

 

Histopathological features of psoriasis:

 

  • Thickening of stratum spinosum (Acanthosis)

  • Hyperkeratosis & Parakeratosis

  • Suprapapillary thinning

  • Clubbing of rete ridges at the base.

  • Kogoj spongiform pustules (collection of neutrophils in Malpighian layer

  • Munro microabscess (collection of neutrophils in stratum corneum)

  • Absence of stratum granulosum

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Camel Foot Appearance of Rete Ridges

 

  • Psoriasis histology often shows elongation of the rete ridges in a pattern resembling the two toes of a camel's foot.

 

 

Image: Regular Acanthosis with Rete Peg Elongation giving Rete Ridges a "Camel Foot" Appearance

 

Option B. Supra Papillary Thinning.

 

  • In psoriasis, the epidermis above the dermal papillae is thinned, which is referred to as suprapapillary thinning.

 

Option C. Kogoj Spongiform Pustules

 

  • This refers to clusters of neutrophils within the epidermis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Psoriasis histopathology typically includes Elongated Rete Ridges, Suprapapillary Thinning, and sometimes the presence of Kogoj Spongiform Pustules, but not wedge-shaped hypergranulosis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 Page No 35.6-7

choices.text: Classic Psoriatic Arthritis typically involves Distal Interphalangeal Joints
Arthritis Mutilans is worst type of Psoriatic Arthritis
Symmetric Oligoarthritis is the most common type of Psoriatic Arthritis.
Methotrexate is the drug of choice for Psoriatic Arthritis

questions.text: Which of the following is the FALSE statement regarding Psoriatic Arthritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Symmetric Oligoarthritis is the most common type of Psoriatic Arthritis

 

Option C.

 

  • Asymmetric oligoarthritis is the most common type of psoriatic arthritis.

 

Psoriatic Arthritis

 

  • This refers to an inflammatory musculoskeletal disease characteristically occurring in individuals with psoriasis.
  • Asymmetric oligoarthritis commonly involves a knee or another large joint with a few small joints in the fingers or toes, often with dactylitis as shown in the image below.

 

 

Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

 

Mild Plaque Psoriasis without Psoriatic Arthritis

 

 

Moderate to Severe Plaque Psoriasis without Psoriatic Arthritis

 

 

Moderate to Severe Plaque Psoriasis with Psoriatic Arthritis

 

 

Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis:

 

*Guttate Psoriasis: Erythromycin (Macrolides)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Classic psoriatic arthritis typically involves Distal Interphalangeal joints

 

Option B. Arthritis mutilans is worst type of Psoriatic arthritis.

 

 

Option D. Methotrexate & apremilast are the first line drugs for the treatment of moderate to severe psoriasis associated with psoriatic arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Asymmetric oligoarthritis is the most common form of psoriatic arthritis, affecting fewer than five joints and usually not the same joints on both sides of the body, while symmetric involvement is more characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 Page No 35.43

ABC of Rheumatology 2018, Wiley Blackwell British Medical Journal Pg No 85

Rooks’ Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 35.31

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with a history of psoriasis vulgaris was referred to the derma OPD with 6 weeks of worsening psoriasis. He was started on captopril for hypertension 4 months prior. On Examination following findings were noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rupoid Psoriasis

 

Option A. 

 

  • Cone shaped heaped up hyperkeratotic lesions Shaped like a shell (limpet) are seen in this Rupioid variety of psoriasis.
  • Captopril (ACE inhibitor) may be associated infrequently with such psoriatic flare ups.
  • Oyster or limpet shell-shaped thick keratotic lesions are referred to as Rupioid lesions (from the Greek rhupos, which means filth).
  • Regular plaque type psoriasis has a white, non-adherent, and thin scaly surface, in contrast to Rupioid forms.
  • There have been reports of severe psoriatic flare-ups and atypical disease forms, such as Rupioid plaques, in patients who are HIV positive and when taking specific medications.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Photosensitive Psoriasis

 

  • It is a type of psoriasis that specifically worsens with exposure to sunlight, which is not indicated in the scenario.

 

Option C. Guttate Psoriasis

 

  • It typically presents as numerous small, drop-like lesions and often follows a streptococcal throat infection.
  • It's not commonly associated with medication use.

 

Option D. Flexural Psoriasis

 

  • This typically affects body folds and is not usually related to medication use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The development of Rupoid psoriasis can be associated with the use of medications such as captopril in a patient with a history of psoriasis vulgaris.

 

Ref: Journal - https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25279472/

choices.text: Female Patients should Avoid getting Pregnant for 6 Months After Therapy

questions.text: A patient was treated with steroids for psoriasis. On stopping the treatment, she develops fever, malaise & lesions as shown in the image below. Pustular psoriasis is suspected with the given history. Now Drug of choice for this condition is to be initiated. Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding the drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Female Patients should Avoid getting Pregnant for 6 Months After Therapy

 

Option D.

 

  • Acitretin is DOC for Pustular psoriasis.

  • Female patients should avoid conception for 3 years after receiving acitretin treatment to prevent retinoid-induced embryopathy.

  • Female patients should avoid conception for 30 days to 3 months if using Isotretinoin.

  • Acitretin is approved for use in the cutaneous manifestations of psoriasis.

 

 

Acitretin:

 

  • It is Contraindicated in persons with hyperlipidaemia (Option A)

  • Is associated with photosensitivity (Option B)

  • It has half-life of 50-70 hours (Option C)

 

Clinical clues for diagnosis of Pustular psoriasis.

 

  • Withdrawal of corticosteroids in a psoriasis patient

  • History of fever & malaise

  • Presence of pustules on a circumscribed, fiery red & oedematous or scaling plaque.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The pharmacological profile and safety considerations of acitretin, particularly its teratogenic potential, necessitating prolonged contraception after cessation of therapy in female patients.

 

Ref: Goodman Gillmans the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics 13th Edition Page No 1276

Online Resources - https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19998529/

Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 18.18, 26.22, 35.33

choices.text: 26-year-old Woman with Impetigo Herpetiformis
8-year-old Boy with Severe Psoriatic Arthritis
17-year-old Boy with Guttate Psoriasis
43-year-old Woman with Erythrodermic Psoriasis

questions.text: In Which of the following cases would you prescribe systemic corticosteroids?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 26-year-old Woman with Impetigo Herpetiformis

 

Option A.

 

  • Impetigo herpetiformis is a rare form of pustular psoriasis occurring during pregnancy.
  • It can be severe and is potentially life-threatening for both the mother and fetus, often requiring systemic corticosteroids as part of the management.
  • Impetigo herpetiformis / pregnancy-related pustular psoriasis, & Erythrodermic Psoriasis in pregnancy are definitive reasons to prescribe systemic steroids in psoriasis.
  • Additionally, steroids may be used to treat acute psoriasis pustular symptoms like ARDS.
  • Tar & dithranol are absolutely contraindicated in pustular psoriasis.
  • The only clear-cut indication for systemic steroids is pregnancy, as they are contraindicated in all other forms of psoriasis due to the risk of sudden withdrawal causing severe pustular or erythrodermic psoriasis.

 

Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Psoriatic Arthritis:

 

  • While systemic corticosteroids might be used in severe psoriatic arthritis, they are generally not the first-line treatment due to potential long-term side effects and the availability of other treatments like DMARDs (Disease-Modifying Antirheumatic Drugs) or biologics.

 

Option C. Guttate Psoriasis:

 

  • Guttate psoriasis often resolves on its own and is usually treated with topical therapies or light therapy rather than systemic corticosteroids, unless other treatments have failed, and the condition is severe.
  • DOC - Erythromycin (Macrolides)

 

Option D. Erythrodermic Psoriasis

 

  • Erythrodermic psoriasis is a severe form of psoriasis that can be life-threatening and may require systemic treatment (Methotrexate); however, systemic corticosteroids are used with caution due to the risk of causing a rebound flare upon withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prescribe systemic corticosteroids for a 26-year-old woman with Impetigo herpetiformis, which is a pustular psoriasis of pregnancy requiring aggressive management due to its potential severity.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 35.35, 35.37

questions.text: A researcher developed drug X for psoriasis that acts on IL-17. Drug X can be all EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Infliximab

 

Option D.

 

  • IL – 17 neutralisers: Secukinumab & Ixekizumab bind to IL – 17 & prevent its binding to the receptor.
  • Brodalumab is a monoclonal antibody against the IL – 17 receptor.

 

These biological drugs are used in cases of Severe Psoriasis & Psoriatic Arthritis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While Brodalumab, Secukinumab, and Ixekizumab are IL-17 inhibitors used in the treatment of psoriasis, Infliximab targets TNF-alpha and is not an IL-17 inhibitor.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 35.46

choices.text: It follows a Chronic Course
It is associated with Fever & Hypocalcemia

questions.text: Ten Days after discharge from the hospital following an Episode of Pharyngitis, a 13-Year-Old Boy developed Skin Lesions on his Trunk and the Proximal Part of his Arms. Which of the following is TRUE about this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Associated with HLA C: 06:02

 

Option B.

 

The picture shows a classical picture of Guttate Psoriasis.

 

  • Following a pharyngitis attack, the clinical stem of small red drop-like lesions on the trunk and arms (illustrated in the image) is suggestive of Guttate psoriasis.
  • HLA C 06:02 is associated with it.
  • A type of psoriasis known as guttate manifests as a sudden onset shower of small lesions that are more prominent on the trunk and proximal limbs.
  • Following infection with group A Streptococcus, it is more prevalent in children and young adultsand frequently the first sign of psoriasis.
  • It can also happen in adults who have plaque psoriasis that first manifested in childhood.
  • Usually, lesions disappear after three months(Not CHRONIC Course) (Option A)
  • Future plaque psoriasis development is a possibility in some patients with acute guttate psoriasis.

 

Guttate Psoriasis Treatment:

 

  • Topical Steroids
  • Antimicrobials - recurrent episodes may be linked to the patient's or a close relative's pharyngeal carriage of the culpable streptococcus.
  • To eliminate chronic streptococcal carriage, a course of semi-synthetic penicillin and rifampin may be necessary.
  • In phototherapy, broadband UVB has a better response than NBUVB.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It follows a Chronic Course:

 

  • Guttate psoriasis, especially in children, often presents as an acute eruption and may resolve spontaneously, making it not typically chronic.

 

Option C. It responds to Acitretin:

 

  • While acitretin can be used in the treatment of psoriasis, it is not the first-line treatment for guttate psoriasis, especially in children.

 

Option D. It is associated with Fever & Hypocalcemia:

 

  • Fever and hypocalcaemia are not typical features of guttate psoriasis.
  • These symptoms are more indicative of pustular psoriasis or other systemic illnesses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Guttate psoriasis, is a condition that often occurs following Streptococcal Infection and is associated with HLA C:06:02.
  • This form of psoriasis typically presents Acutely and may Resolve without progressing to a chronic course.
  • DOC - Erythromycin (Macrolides)

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 35.15 & 35.16

Andrew’s Diseases of Skin Clinical Dermatology – 12 Edition Page No 188-189

Online resources - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482498/

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the Clinic with a 2-Week History of Progressive Skin Redness and scaling covering more than 90% of his Body Surface Area. He reports associated Pruritus and Malaise. His Medical History is significant for Psoriasis, which has been well-controlled with Topical Therapies. On examination, his Vital Signs are within Normal Limits, but he Appears Uncomfortable due to the Skin Changes. Laboratory Tests reveal an Elevated Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR) and Mild Eosinophilia. What is the most likely Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Erythroderma

 

Option C.

 

Erythroderma

 

  • It is characterized by generalized erythema and scaling affecting more than 90% of the body surface area, often with systemic symptoms like fever and malaise.

 

 

  • This patient’s history of psoriasis, a common predisposing factor, coupled with the extensive skin involvement and systemic symptoms, strongly suggests erythroderma.
  • Erythroderma can be a complication of pre-existing dermatoses like psoriasis, contact dermatitis, atopic dermatitis, Pityriasis rubra pilaris, Mycosis fungoides & Seborrheic dermatitis.

 

Complications with Erythroderma

 

  1. Protein & Electrolyte Imbalance
  2. Dehydration
  3. Sepsis

 

Management of Erythroderma

 

  1. OPD Based Treatment Plan → Mild Potency Topical Steroids
  2. Severe Form of Erythroderma → Hospitalise → Systemic Steroids
  3. Psoriatic Erythroderma: Methotrexate, Cyclosporine & Anti TNF Therapy

 

Drug of choice for different types of Psoriasis:

 

* Guttate Psoriasis: Erythromycin (Macrolides)

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute Generalized Exanthematous Pustulosis (AGEP):

 

  • It is characterized by the rapid onset of numerous sterile pustules, fever, and leukocytosis.
  • The absence of pustular lesions in this patient makes AGEP less likely.

 

Option B. Drug-Induced Hypersensitivity Syndrome:

 

  • It typically presents with fever, rash, and multiorgan involvement, often 2-6 weeks after exposure to a new medication.
  • This patient’s symptoms are more consistent with erythroderma and there's no mention of new medication use or organ involvement.

 

Option D. Pemphigus Vulgaris:

 

  • It is an autoimmune blistering disorder that presents with flaccid blisters and erosions but not the widespread erythema and scaling seen in erythroderma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Erythroderma in a patient with extensive skin redness and scaling, particularly in the context of a history of psoriasis.

 

Ref: Bolognia Dermatology Textbook 4th Edition Page No 175

Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 35.35, 35.37

IADVL Textbook of Dermatology 2nd Edition Page No 441

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of joint pain and stiffness, primarily in her hands and feet. She mentions that the pain is worse in the morning and improves with activity. On examination, there is noticeable swelling of the distal interphalangeal joints. She also has silvery, scaly plaques on her elbows and knees. Her family history is positive for psoriasis. There is no history of gastrointestinal symptoms or eye inflammation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Psoriatic Arthritis

 

Option C.

 

  • It is characterized by inflammation of the joints, often affecting the distal interphalangeal joints, which is a distinguishing feature from other types of arthritis.
  • The presence of psoriatic skin lesions and a family history of psoriasis further supports this diagnosis.
  • Psoriatic arthritis can cause morning stiffness and joint pain.
  • Nail involvement (Pitting, Onycholysis) is also commonly seen in patients of psoriatic arthritis.
  • Psoriatic Arthritis is associated with HLA B27.

 

 

 

In the above image of Psoriatic arthritis, we can NOTE the following findings:

 

  • Asymmetric involvement of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints.
  • A “sausage” digit (third digit bilaterally) results from involvement of both the DIP and PIP joints.
  • Yellowing, thickening and crumbling of several fingernails.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid Arthritis:

 

  • It typically presents with symmetric polyarthritis affecting the proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints.
  • While morning stiffness is a common feature, the presence of psoriatic skin lesions is not characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option B. Gout:

 

  • It usually presents with acute, severe pain and swelling, often starting in the big toe (podagra).
  • Chronic gout can affect other joints, but it is less likely to present with the skin findings seen in psoriasis.

 

Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis:

 

  • It is more commonly associated with lower back pain and stiffness that improves with exercise but worsens with rest.
  • It also often presents with sacroiliitis and enthesitis, which are not described in the patient's presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diagnose psoriatic arthritis in a patient presenting with joint pain and stiffness in the distal interphalangeal joints, morning stiffness, and associated psoriatic skin lesions, especially with a family history of psoriasis.

 

Ref: Bolognia Dermatology Textbook 4th Edition Page No 148

Rooks’ Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 7.7

questions.text: A patient was treated with steroids for psoriasis. On stopping the treatment, he develops fever, malaise, and lesions as seen in the image below. What is the Most Probable Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pustular Psoriasis

 

Option A.

 

  • The given clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of Pustular psoriasis.
  • Clinical clues for diagnosis of Pustular psoriasis:
    • Pustular Lesions seen after withdrawal of corticosteroids in a psoriasis patient
    • History of fever & malaise
    • Presence of pustules on a circumscribed, fiery red & edematous or scaling plaque

 

Acitretin:

 

  • Approved for use in the cutaneous manifestations of psoriasis.
  • It is the DOC for Pustular psoriasis.
  • Female patients should avoid conception for 3 years after receiving acitretin treatment to prevent retinoid induced embryopathy.
  • Is associated with photosensitivity.
  • It has half-life of 50-70 hours

 

Absolute Contraindications:

 

  • Pregnant women
  • Women who are planning to get pregnant
  • Breast-feeding

 

Relative Contraindications:

 

  • Leukopenia
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Hypercholesterolemia
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Significant hepatic or renal disease

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Staphylococcal infection:

 

  • While staphylococcal infections can cause skin lesions, there's no direct link provided between steroid withdrawal and the onset of such infections.
  • In fact,steroid usage would initiate such staphylococcal infections, not withdrawal.

 

Option C: Acute Generalized Exanthematous pustulosis (AGEP):

 

  • AGEP is typically a reaction to medications not due to steroid withdrawal, and its presentation can be similar to pustular psoriasis.

 

Option D: Sub Corneal Pustulosis Dermatosis is also known as Sneddon-Wilkinson disease.

 

  • It is a rare condition, characterised by pustules that appear in crops over months or years.
  • However, there is no direct link between steroid withdrawal and SCPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient with a history of psoriasis presents with fever, malaise, and widespread pustules following the abrupt withdrawal of systemic corticosteroids, consider pustular psoriasis as the probable diagnosis.
  • This condition can be a severe, life-threatening variant of psoriasis that requires prompt medical attention and management.

 

Ref: Goodman Gillman’s he Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics – 13th Edition Page No 1276

Online Resources - https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19998529/

Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Page No 18.18, 26.22, 35.28, 35.33

questions.text: A 36-year-old male with a 10-year history of plaque psoriasis not adequately controlled with topical therapies is being considered for systemic treatment. Which of the following treatments is NOT an anti-TNF alpha inhibitor commonly used for psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alefacept

 

Option C.

 

  • Alefacept is the first biologic agent approved by the US Food and Drug Administration for the treatment of psoriasis.
  • It is not an anti-TNF alpha inhibitor.
  • It is a fusion protein that interferes with lymphocyte activation, which was used in the treatment of psoriasis but is not part of the anti-TNF alpha category and has been discontinued in the United States.
  • Alefacept is a recombinant fusion protein that works by binding to the CD2 receptor on T cells.
  • It inhibits the activation of T cells by interfering with the LFA-3/CD2 interaction, which is necessary for T cells to receive the co-stimulatory signals that are essential for their activation, proliferation, and survival.

 

 

  • By blocking this interaction, alefacept reduces the number of circulating memory T cells (CD4+CD45RO+ and CD8+CD45RO+), leading to a decrease in the overall count of total lymphocytes.
  • This reduction in activated T cells is crucial because these cells play a significant role in the pathogenesis of psoriasis, driving the inflammatory process that leads to the characteristic plaques.

 

List of anti-TNF alpha inhibitors:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Infliximab:

 

  • It is an anti-TNF alpha inhibitor used in the treatment of moderate to severe plaque psoriasis, especially when it's associated with psoriatic arthritis.

 

Option B. Adalimumab:

 

  • It is another anti-TNF alpha inhibitor indicated for the treatment of both psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis, reflecting its efficacy in treating skin lesions as well as joint inflammation.

 

Option D. Etanercept:

 

  • It is also an anti-TNF alpha inhibitor that has been used in the treatment of chronic moderate to severe plaque psoriasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alefacept is not an anti-TNF alpha inhibitor and is no longer available for the treatment of psoriasis, unlike infliximab, adalimumab, and etanercept, which are anti-TNF alpha therapies used in this condition.

 

Ref: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 2257

Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Page No 35.40

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presented to the dermatology OPD with a skin lesion. On examination, there is a well-demarcated plaque on the right knee which was covered with silvery white scales. it has been growing slowly for the past 4 years. A diagnosis of psoriasis was made. Which of the following variants of the given condition will demonstrate the development of pinpoint bleeding on scrapping the scaly lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Psoriasis Vulgaris

 

Option D.

 

Psoriasis Vulgaris / Chronic Plaque Psoriasis:

 

  • It is the most common form of psoriasis, characterized by well-demarcated plaques with silvery scales.
  • The Auspitz sign, pinpoint bleeding when scales are scraped off, is a classic finding in psoriasis vulgaris, which can be elicited during the physical examination of the plaques.
  • However, the Auspitz sign is neither sensitive or specific for psoriasis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pustular Psoriasis:

 

  • It is a rare form of psoriasis characterized by white pustules surrounded by red skin.
  • While it may have scaling, the hallmark is the pustules rather than the bleeding seen with plaque psoriasis.

 

Option B. Guttate Psoriasis:

 

  • It typically presents as numerous small, scaly, red or pink droplet-like lesions (papules) rather than thick plaques and does not typically demonstrate the Auspitz sign.

 

 

Option C. Erythrodermic Psoriasis:

 

  • It involves widespread redness and exfoliation of the skin over a large area, and while scaling is present, pinpoint bleeding is not a characteristic feature.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Identify the Auspitz sign, which is indicative of psoriasis vulgaris, characterized by pinpoint bleeding upon scraping of the silvery scales from a psoriatic plaque.

 

Ref: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 19th Edition Page No 347

Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 Page No 35.5

questions.text:
Following is the list of some Skin Diseases:

 

  1. Lichen Planus
  2. Xeroderma Pigmentosum
  3. Psoriasis
  4. Vitiligo

 

Which of the following combinations of Diseases which are mentioned above can be treated with Ultraviolet (UV) Light?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 4 are Correct.

 

UV light therapy is a well-established treatment modality for several dermatological conditions due to its immunomodulatory and anti-inflammatory effects.

 

  • This is most commonly known for its role in the treatment of psoriasis.
     

 

1. Lichen Planus:

 

  • UV Light, Narrow Band UVB, has been used to treat lichen planus, especially for widespread or refractory cases.

 

 

2. Xeroderma pigmentosum:

 

  • It is characterized by extreme sensitivity to UV rays due to a defect in DNA repair mechanisms.
  • UV light exposure can be harmful to patients with this condition, making it a contraindication for UV light therapy.

 

3. Psoriasis:

 

  • UV light therapy, including PUVA (psoralen combined with UVA) and UVB phototherapy, is effective in the treatment of psoriasis.

 

 

4. Vitiligo:

 

  • UVB phototherapy, particularly narrowband UVB, is a mainstay treatment for vitiligo, inducing repigmentation by stimulating melanocytes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Xeroderma pigmentosum (2) cannot be treated with UV light therapy and is, in fact, a condition where UV exposure must be avoided.

 

Option C: Lichen planus (1) is missing, which can be treated with UV light therapy.

 

Option D: Includes Xeroderma pigmentosum (2), which is not treated with UV light therapy due to the condition's UV sensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • UV light therapy is indicated for lichen planus, psoriasis, and vitiligo but is contraindicated in xeroderma pigmentosum due to the harmful effects of UV light in this DNA repair-deficient condition.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 Page No 35.63

Wolverton Comprehensive Dermatologic Drug Therapy Page No 265

questions.text: Identify the finding associated with the condition shown in the image below which is Characterized by Development of Morphologically Similar Lesions along the Lines of Trauma:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Isomorphic Phenomenon

 

Option C.

 

Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon:

 

  • It is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin.
  • The new lesions have iso (same) & morphic (morphology) as existing lesions.
  • Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

 

 

  • The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

 

 

Some rare causes of true Koebner phenomenon are:

 

  • Darier’s disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, EMF erythema multiforme, Kaposi’s sarcoma &lichen nitidus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Gottron's Papule

 

  • It is seen associated with Dermatomyositis.

 

Option B. Nikolsky’s Sign:

 

  • Description: Positive when the superficial epidermis moves laterally with slight rubbing or pressure, leading to the separation of the epidermis from the underlying dermis as shown in the below image.

 

 

Option D: Meyerson Phenomenon

 

  • It is a Melanocytic Nevus that has developed an eczematous ring around it as seen in the image below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Isomorphic Phenomenon (Koebner Phenomenon) is the appearance of skin lesions similar to a primary disease along areas of skin trauma, which is important for diagnosis and management in dermatology.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 123.2

questions.text: The image shown below is a Pathognomonic Finding in Psoriasis. What is it Called?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subungual Oil Drop Sign

 

Option B.

 

  • Salmon patches or subungual oil drop sign is extremely specific pathognomonic sign of nail psoriasis.
  • It looks like an oil droplet and is a yellowish, reddish discoloration in the nail bed.

 

Psoriasis:

 

  • It an inflammatory non-infectious disease. There is an increased number of activated Th1, Th17& Th22 cells with a deficiency of Th2 cells.
  • Genetic predisposition is present in type 1 plaque psoriasis & guttate psoriasis with HLA C: 06: 02
  • About 5-30% of patients with cutaneous psoriasis have psoriatic arthritis (PsA).
  • At any given time, 40% of psoriasis cases have changes to their nails. Nail psoriasis is linked to more severe psoriasis, longer disease duration, psoriatic arthritis, and family history of the condition.

 

Nail Changes in Psoriasis:

 

 

  • Salmon patches or subungual oil drop sign is extremely specific pathognomonic sign of nail psoriasis. It looks like an oil droplet and is a yellowish, reddish discoloration in the nail bed.
  • However, the most frequent symptom is nail pitting.
  • Individual pits are irregular in shape and uniform in depth. These nail pits, also referred to as Thimble pits, are brought on by the proximal nail matrix's involvement.
  • Sub-Ungual Hyperkeratosis, Splinter Hemorrhages, and Distal onycholysis are additional symptoms of nail bed disease.
  • There might also be Leukonychia.

 

 

  • Pitting Affecting the Finger Nails.

 

 

  • Onycholysis along with pitting and salmon patches in fingernails

 

 

  • Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis

 

 

  • Nail plate thickening and crumbling resulting in complete nail dystrophy
  • Features of Nail Psoriasis–Mnemonic
  • "Nail - POLISH"
  • P – Pitting (Most common feature)
  • O- Oil drop sign (Pathognomonic), Onycholysis
  • L - Leukonychia
  • I - Irregular pitting pattern
  • S - Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H - Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

 

Explanation:

 

Option D: Nail Pterygium

 

  • It is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. Fusion of proximal nail fold and nail bed with destruction of nail plate, leads to pterygium as shown in the below image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Subungual Oil Drop Sign is a specific clinical finding in Nail Psoriasis, which presents as a Yellow to Orange Discoloration under the Nail Plate, distinguishing it from other nail changes such as Pitting, Thinning, or Pterygium.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 Page No 35.4-35.6, 35.9

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition Page No 333

questions.text: Identify the Type of Psoriasis in the given picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Guttate

 

Option A.

 

The picture shows a classical picture of Guttate Psoriasis.

 

  • Following a pharyngitis attack, the clinical stem of small red drop-like lesions on the trunk and arms (illustrated in the image) is suggestive of Guttate psoriasis.
  • HLA C 06:02 is associated with it.
  • A type of psoriasis known as guttate manifests as a sudden onset shower of small lesions that are more prominent on the trunk and proximal limbs. Following infection with group A Streptococcus, it is more prevalent in children and young adults and frequently the first sign of psoriasis. It can also happen in adults who have plaque psoriasis that first manifested in childhood.
  • Usually, lesions disappear after three months. Future plaque psoriasis development is a possibility in some patients with acute guttate psoriasis.

 

Guttate psoriasis Treatment:

 

  • Topical steroids
  • Antimicrobials - recurrent episodes may be linked to the patient's or a close relative's pharyngeal carriage of the culpable streptococcus. To eliminate chronic streptococcal carriage, a course of semi-synthetic penicillin and rifampin may be necessary.
  • In phototherapy, broadband UVB has a better response than NBUVB.

 

Note:

 

  • Plaque and follicular psoriasis both have a chronic course.
  • Patients with pustular psoriasis may experience cachexia, hypocalcemia, erythroderma, and fever.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Erythrodermic Psoriasis:

 

  • This is a severe form of psoriasis where the skin appears extensively red and inflamed.
  • The skin sheds in sheets rather than scales.
  • It lacks the distinct drop-shaped papules of guttate psoriasis.

 

Option C. Pustular Psoriasis:

 

  • Characterized by white blisters of non-infectious pus surrounded by red skin.
  • The main feature is the presence of pustules, which are not described in your picture.

 

Option D. Inverse Psoriasis:

 

  • Found in the folds of the skin, such as under the armpits, in the groin, under the breasts, and other areas.
  • Appears as very red, smooth, and shiny lesions.
  • Unlike other forms, it lacks the classic scales seen in the "Rain Drop" pattern of guttate psoriasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Identify Guttate Psoriasis by its classic presentation of numerous small, drop-like papules, often appearing after a streptococcal infection, which is distinct from other psoriasis types that have different presentations and localizations.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 35.4, 35.15 & 35.16

Andrew’s Diseases of Skin Clinical Dermatology – 12 Edition Page No 188-189

Online Resources - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482498

questions.text: A patient with a known case of chronic plaque psoriasis with more than 50% skin involvement presents to you. Which of the following will you NOT recommend?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oral Steroids

 

Option C.

 

  • Oral/Systemic Steroids are not used in the management of Chronic Plaque Psoriasis. Topical Steroids may be used.
  • The only clear-cut indication for systemic steroids is Pregnancy, as they are contraindicated in all other forms of psoriasis due to the risk of sudden withdrawal causing severe pustular or erythrodermic psoriasis.

 

Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Oral Methotrexate:

 

  • Methotrexate is an anti-metabolite and immune modulator commonly used as a systemic treatment for moderate to severe plaque psoriasis. It is effective in reducing the proliferation of skin cells and has anti-inflammatory properties.

 

Option B. NB UVB (Narrowband Ultraviolet B):

 

  • NB UVB phototherapy is a well-established treatment for moderate to severe plaque psoriasis. It works by reducing skin cell proliferation and modulating the immune system.

 

Option D. Oral cyclosporine:

 

  • Cyclosporine is a calcineurin inhibitor that suppresses the immune system and is used for severe psoriasis. It is effective for quick control of the disease due to its potent immune suppressive effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oral steroids are not recommended for the long-term treatment of chronic plaque psoriasis due to the risk of disease exacerbation upon steroid withdrawal and the potential for serious side effects with long-term use.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 35.22, 35.35, 35.37

questions.text: Irregular pitting of the nails with subungual hyperkeratosis is seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psoriasis

 

Option B.

 

  • Irregular pitting of the nails with subungual hyperkeratosis is most commonly seen in psoriasis, which is a chronic inflammatory skin condition.

 

Psoriasis:

 

  • It is an inflammatory non-infectious disease characterized by an imbalance in T-cell subsets. There is an elevated number of activated Th1, Th17, and Th22 cells, while Th2 cells are deficient.

 

Cytokines in Psoriasis:

 

 

  • Genetic predisposition: In Type 1 plaque psoriasis and guttate psoriasis with HLA C: 06:02 association.
  • Around 5-30% of individuals with cutaneous psoriasis also develop psoriatic arthritis (PsA), a condition affecting the joints.
  • Psoriasis can affect the skin and joints, leading to psoriatic arthritis.
  • About 5-30% of patients with cutaneous psoriasis have psoriatic arthritis (PsA).
  • At any given time, 40% of psoriasis cases have changes to their nails.
  • Nail psoriasis is linked to more severe psoriasis, longer disease duration, psoriatic arthritis, and family history of the condition.

 

Nail Changes in Psoriasis:

 

 

  • Salmon patches or subungual oil drop sign is extremely specific pathognomonic sign of nail psoriasis. It looks like an oil droplet and is a yellowish, reddish discoloration in the nail bed.
  • However, the most frequent symptom is nail pitting.
  • Individual pits are irregular in shape and uniform in depth. These nail pits, also referred to as Thimble pits, are brought on by the proximal nail matrix's involvement.
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis are additional symptoms of nail bed disease.
  • There might also be leukonychia.

 

 

  • Pitting affecting the fingernails.

 

 

  • Onycholysis along with pitting and salmon patches in fingernails

 

 

  • Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis

 

 

  • Nail plate thickening and crumbling resulting in complete nail dystrophy

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis–Mnemonic

 

"Nail - POLISH"

  • P – Pitting (Most common feature)
  • O- Oil drop sign (Pathognomonic), Onycholysis
  • L - Leukonychia
  • I - Irregular pitting pattern
  • S - Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H - Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lichen Planus:

 

  • Lichen planus can affect the Nails and produce Nail Changes, but the common manifestations are Nail Thinning, Ridging, or even complete Loss of the Nail.
  • Pterygium Formation, where there's Scarring of the Cuticle Area leading to the Nail's progressive Loss, can also be seen.
  • While Lichen Planus can cause Nail Pitting, it's typically not associated with Subungual Hyperkeratosis, a feature more consistent with Psoriasis.

 

Option C. Vitiligo:

 

  • Vitiligo is a disorder where there's a loss of pigment-producing cells (melanocytes) leading to white patches on the skin.
  • It doesn't typically produce pitting of nails.

 

Option D. Alopecia Areata:

 

  • Geometric fine stippled pitting (Superficial, Regular, Fine) of the nails is the most likely expected finding as shown below.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Psoriasis is the condition most commonly associated with irregular nail pitting and subungual hyperkeratosis among the options provided.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 4.9, 35.4-35.34, 37.12, 41.1, 41.21 89.28-33

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition Page No 333

questions.text: A patient presented with lesions as shown in the image below and later developed arthritis also. What is the treatment of choice for a patient who presented with the following findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methotrexate

 

Option A.

 

  • The patient has dactylitis of multiple digits, on toes sharply demarcated red Papulosquamous lesions on both toes all of which point towards a diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis.
  • Methotrexate and apremilast are the first-line drugs for the treatment of moderate to severe psoriasis associated with psoriatic arthritis.

 

Psoriatic Arthritis:

 

  • It refers to an inflammatory musculoskeletal disease characteristically occurring in individuals with psoriasis.
  • Asymmetric oligoarthritis commonly involves a knee or another large joint with a few small joints in the fingers or toes, often with dactylitis.
  • Asymmetric oligoarthritis is the most common type of psoriatic arthritis.
  • Classic psoriatic arthritis typically involves Distal Interphalangeal joints.
  • Arthritis mutilans is worst type of Psoriatic arthritis
  • Methotrexate & apremilast are the first line drugs for the treatment of moderate to severe psoriasis associated with psoriatic arthritis.

 

Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

 

  • Mild Plaque Psoriasis without Psoriatic Arthritis

 

 

  • Moderate to Severe Plaque Psoriasis without Psoriatic Arthritis

 

 

  • Moderate to Severe Plaque Psoriasis with Psoriatic Arthritis

 

 

  • Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Cyclophosphamide –

 

  • This is a cytotoxic medication most often used in the treatment of cancers and severe autoimmune diseases.
  • It is not typically used as a first-line treatment for arthritis due to its significant side effect profile.

 

Option C. Mycophenolate Mofetil –

 

  • This medication is used as an immunosuppressant in organ transplantation and certain autoimmune conditions.
  • While it may be used in the management of connective tissue diseases, it is not the first-line treatment for psoriatic arthritis or rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option D. Rituximab –

 

  • This is a monoclonal antibody that targets CD20-positive B cells and is used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis after other treatments have failed. It is not typically the first choice of treatment for new-onset arthritis associated with skin lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Methotrexate and apremilast are the first-line drugs for the treatment of moderate to severe psoriasis associated with psoriatic arthritis.

 

Ref: ABC of Rheumatology 2018, Wiley Blackwell British Medical Journal Pg no 85

Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 35.31, 35.43

Harrisons Principle of Internal Medicine 20th Edition Page No 2571-2572

Katzungs Basic & Clinical Pharmacology 12th Edition Page No 645

questions.text: Which of the following are having a established association?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Psoriasis & Metabolic Syndrome

 

Option C.

 

Psoriasis

 

  • It is well-established to have an association with metabolic syndrome.
  • Multiple studies have shown that patients with psoriasis are at a higher risk of developing metabolic syndrome, which is a cluster of conditions including hypertension, high blood sugar, excess body fat around the waist, and abnormal cholesterol levels.
  • This association is believed to be due to systemic inflammation.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Lichen Planus

 

  • It is not typically associated with malignant melanoma.
  • Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory skin condition, and while it may have an increased risk of squamous cell carcinoma in chronic cases, it is not directly linked to malignant melanoma.

 

Option B: Melasma

 

  • It is a condition characterized by hyperpigmented patches, mainly on the face.
  • There is no established association between melasma and malignant melanoma.

 

Option D: Vitiligo

 

  • It is an autoimmune condition that causes depigmentation of the skin.
  • It has not been shown to have an established association with metabolic syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • There is a recognized link between psoriasis and metabolic syndrome, reflecting the systemic nature of inflammation in psoriasis and its implications for comorbid conditions.

 

Ref: Bolognia Dermatology Textbook 4th Edition Page No 190

Online resources: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29241748/
